page.paragraph: Listen to a conversation between a student and a professor.
Hi, Anna. How are you today?
Just fine, thank you.
Did you want to see me about something? Do you have a question?
Yes.
OK…well…what's your question?
Well, it's…um…about the unit grade…you know…you just gave out unit grades…for the first unit of the public policy class.
Yes, I did.
And…well…I guess I was kind of surprised at the unit grade.
You…You were? Why?…It wasn't the grade you were expecting?
Um, not quite.
Ah, but my grading system is very clear, I think. There shouldn't have been any surprises.
Well, you see, I got a high grade on the unit exam. I mean…it was a 95, and I think you said the highest grade on the exam was a 97, and I had almost the top grade, you know, a 95….
Yes?
So I was kind of surprised to get a C for a unit grade. I was expecting an A…because of the exam grade.

Oh, I see what the problem is…well, I thought my grading system was clear, but I guess it's not so clear after all. You know, my grading system was on the syllabus I gave out on the first day of class…You were in class on the first day, weren't you?
Yes, I was.
And you did get the syllabus?
Yes, I did.
And I discussed the grading system the first day…the grading system that was on the syllabus…. That wasn't clear to you?
Um…I guess not, because I thought that if I got a grade of 95 on the exam, an A on the exam, then I thought I'd be getting an A for the unit grade.
Ah, you see, that's what the problem is. If you look on the syllabus, it says that the exam grade is only 50 percent of the unit grade.
Only 50 percent?

That's right. The other 50 percent of the grade comes from attendance and participation during class. You see, only part of your grade is learning the course material for the exam. The other really important part is to be able to use the information…to…ah…apply the information by interacting with the other students in class. You know what, let me look at my grade book…You were absent twice? You missed two class meetings?
Um…yes, I did, but I got notes from one of my friends, so I know what was covered in the two class meetings I missed…well, that's why I was able to do so well on the exam.

But class isn't just about getting information from me by taking notes of what I say. It's about discussions of the material, applying it to various situations…Now, when you were in class, just how often did you join in discussing, you know, comment on the material, uh…debate with other students about how the course material can be applied to various situations?
Well, not much…not at all, I guess.

So your grade for attendance and participation was very low, because you didn't attend regularly, and when you did attend you didn't take part in the class discussions…and that was 50 percent of your grade. Do you understand now why your unit grade was a C and not an A?
Yeah, I see that now.
Uh-hmm. And…and you understand what you need to do in the next two units?
Yes, I actually do now.
